title: 109_s1019
content: The "Welcome Home G.I. Bill Act of 2005" includes improvements in education, housing benefits, and health benefits for veterans. It consists of different sections such as Montgomery G.I. Bill improvements, improved education benefits for reserve component members, increase in home purchase benefits, extension of transitional health care for uninsured veterans, and clarification of medical exams. The "Welcome Home G.I. Bill Act of 2005" includes amendments to increase educational benefits and extend the duration of educational assistance for veterans. This includes a 150 percent increase in basic educational allowance for eligible individuals under certain sections of the title. The curr_chunk discusses the eligibility criteria for individuals serving on active duty outside the US for at least 6 consecutive months. The requirement is waived for those discharged for specific reasons such as a service-connected disability or preexisting medical condition. The Secretary of Defense shall refund all amounts reduced from the basic pay of individuals discharged after 5 consecutive months of service on active duty for specific reasons such as reduction in force or non-disability physical or mental conditions. Upon completion of an approved course of education, individuals referred to in the previous section may use increased basic educational assistance to repay Federal student loans. Payment under this provision cannot exceed the individual's entitlement. The specified period for eligibility begins on September 11, 2001, and ends five years after the enactment of the Welcome Home G.I. Bill Act of 2005. The Welcome Home G.I. Bill Act of 2005 extends the duration of payments for individuals referred to in specific sections of the title. The amendment allows for a substitution of '48 months' for '36 months' in certain cases. Conforming amendments adjust the specified periods and amounts for eligibility and refunds under the Act. The amendment extends payment duration for individuals under specific sections of the title, allowing for a substitution of '48 months' for '36 months' in certain cases. Conforming amendments adjust eligibility periods and refund amounts under the Act. SEC. 102. IMPROVED EDUCATION BENEFITS FOR RESERVE COMPONENT MEMBERS SUPPORTING CONTINGENCY OPERATIONS AND CERTAIN OTHER OPERATIONS. SEC. 102 of the Welcome Home G.I. Bill Act of 2005 increases educational assistance rates for reserve component members called to active service during war or national emergencies. It also extends the duration of educational assistance to 48 months in certain cases. The amendment allows reserve component members to use educational assistance to repay federal student loans, with a maximum payment equal to their available entitlement under the chapter. The amendment allows reserve component members to use educational assistance to repay federal student loans made under title IV of the Higher Education Act of 1965. SEC. 103. INCREASE IN HOME PURCHASE BENEFITS. The new section 3709 of Chapter 37 of title 38, United States Code, allows the Secretary of Defense to provide a $5,000 payment to veterans for downpayment on a home purchase after performing eligible service. This payment must be used within five years of completing the service. The Secretary of Defense can provide a $5,000 payment to veterans for a home downpayment after eligible service, which must be used within five years. Veterans must show they have not previously obtained a loan under this chapter. Eligible service includes active duty after September 11, 2001, outside the US as part of a contingency or combat operation for at least 6 consecutive months. The table of sections in chapter 37 of the title is amended to include a new item after section 3708. The provision of downpayment toward home purchase for veterans performing eligible service is considered a qualified military benefit under section 3709 of title 38, United States Code. This benefit is excluded from gross income according to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. No increase in basis of property from excluded amounts under this section. Amendment applies to payments made after enactment date in taxable years ending after that date. Title II focuses on improvements in health benefits, specifically the extension of transitional health care for certain uninsured veterans. Title II focuses on improvements in health benefits, specifically the extension of transitional health care for certain uninsured veterans under Section 1145 of title 10, United States Code. Eligible veterans can receive transitional health care for up to five years if they are not covered under any group health plan provided by an employer or spouse's employer. Eligible veterans are defined as individuals who served in the military after September 11, 2001. After September 11, 2001, veterans deployed outside the US for at least 6 consecutive months as part of a contingency or combat operation are eligible for transitional health care if discharged under conditions other than dishonorable. SEC. 202. CLARIFICATION OF PREDEPLOYMENT AND POSTDEPLOYMENT MEDICAL EXAMS. The system described in subsection (a) of section 1074f of title 10, United States Code, is amended to include predeployment and postdeployment medical examinations to record the medical condition of members before and during deployment. The predeployment examination involves a self-administered survey and a clinical examination by Department of Defense medical personnel, including the collection of clinical data and information on physical and mental health. The postdeployment medical examination includes a self-administered survey and clinical examination by Department of Defense medical personnel. It involves assessing mental health, screening for prevalent diseases, and referral for further treatment if needed. The examination also includes gathering information on relevant exposures during deployment, such as combat experiences and screening for post-traumatic stress disorder. Postdeployment medical examinations are required when a member is redeployed or leaves an operational area.
